name: 2,4-bis(1-methylethylidene)cyclobutanone
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2373

name: 2,4-bis(1-methylethylidene)cyclobutanone
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2373
Reason: The target compound, 2,4-bis(1-methylethylidene)cyclobutanone, contains several structural features that influence its melting point. The basic cyclobutanone structure has a melting point typically around 50°C for unsubstituted cyclobutanone derivatives. The incorporation of double bonds (as in alpha, beta-unsaturated ketones) tends to lower the melting point due to less efficient packing, which might reduce it by approximately 5°C per double bond. However, the steric hindrance and increased molecular weight due to the tert-butyl groups (1-methylethylidene) can increase the melting point. Each tertiary butyl group could contribute an increase of approximately 10°C, considering there are four such groups. Therefore: Basic cyclobutanone: 50, Reduction by double bonds: -10 (2 * -5), Increase by tert-butyl groups: +40 (4 * 10).
